awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Structural Fault Diagnosis and Prognosis Utilizing a Physics-guided Data Analytics Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
The timely and accurate diagnosis and prognosis of fault conditions in mechanical structures and civil infrastructure using real-time measurements can play a critical role in ensuring the safe and sustainable operation of these structures.  This, however, is inherently difficult because structural degradations and faults usually have very subtle characteristic signature with infinitely many possible patterns and profiles, which is further compounded by various uncertainties. The existing techniques fall short in addressing these challenges.  The overarching goal of this research is to create a new framework of fault diagnosis and prognosis enabled by physics-guided data.  This framework is built upon the integration of computational intelligence with high-fidelity modeling and analysis and the adaptation of a highly promising, non-contact sensor-structure interaction mechanism. The new modeling framework will lead to useful diagnostic and prognostic tools in many areas such as aerospace, marine, transportation, infrastructure, energy and power.  This project will contribute significantly to the workforce training by promoting the interdisciplinary research of computing, sensing, and statistical analysis, and by promoting the concepts of resilient and sustainable systems.

The research encompasses a series of inter-related components.  High-fidelity multi-scale physical models capable of characterizing high-frequency dynamic responses of complex structural systems with high efficiency will be created.  Data-driven calibration of the physic-guided model to address the model inadequacy and bias issues will be formulated and established. Fault diagnosis algorithm through compressed sensing technique based on the calibrated physics-guided model will be developed.  Fault prognosis through statistically rigorous mixed effects models and multivariate Gaussian process models will be synthesized.  Combined with the adaptive sensor-structure integration mechanism, collectively these contributions form a new framework that can lead to orders-of-magnitude enhancement in sensitivity and robustness of structural fault diagnosis and prognosis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The timely and accurate diagnosis and prognosis of fault conditions in mechanical structures using real-time, online sensor measurements play a critical role in ensuring the secure and sustainable operations of various structural systems in aerospace, marine, transportation and infrastructure, and energy and power industries.  Such a mission, however, is inherently difficult, because structural degradations/faults usually have extremely small characteristic lengths with infinitely many possible patterns/profiles, which is further compounded by noise and various uncertainties. The existing techniques fall short in addressing these challenges.  The conventional pure data-driven and knowledge-based methods require comprehensive training datasets and the generality of the results is often questionable.  The difficulty in physics-driven approach, such as the commonly used finite element analysis, is that it requires a very high dimensional model to reflect the impact of small-sized faults and thus it is very computational expensive. In this collaborative research project, our goal is to create a new framework of fault diagnosis and prognosis enabled by physics-guided data analytics.  This framework is built upon the integration of computational intelligence with high-fidelity modeling/analysis. Taking advantage of the emerging sensing technology, significantly enlarged measurement dataset can be collected.  With enriched data and high fidelity model, advanced data analytics techniques utilizing compressed sensing, parametric and nonparametric learning for information fusion are established for effective structure fault diagnosis and prognosis.

During the course of the project, many such methodologies have been successfully established. These methodologies can be roughly put into two categories.

(1)    Fault diagnosis algorithm through integration of high fidelity physics model and advanced data analytics methods. Through a careful analysis of the physics model, the necessary measurements that can guarantee the structural fault being identified are selected based on a compressed sensing formulation. This method can effectively address the difficulty caused by underdetermined problem in structural fault diagnosis. A Bayesian optimization approach is further developed to achieve fault (including location and severity) identification. The advantage of this approach is that only limited number of evaluations of the high fidelity simulation model are needed for the fault diagnosis.

(2)    Fault prognosis through information fusion.  One significant advantage provided by the modern condition monitoring system is that we can monitor the operation of a large number of structures/systems with ease. This provides us great opportunities to establish information fusion and sharing techniques to achieve accurate prognosis through learning from each other?s degradation evolving path. In this project, we developed statistically rigorous mixed effects model and powerful multi-output Gaussian process models to fuse the information from historical degradation progression paths to achieve accurate prognosis even with limited observations in the structure currently under study.   

The research team conducted thorough literature survey on these topics and addressed the research gaps. The advantages of the newly developed methodologies are validated through both simulation and real world data. The research results have been summarized in multiple publications in peer reviewed journals and disseminated in research conferences. The success of the project will push the capabilities of the structure fault diagnosis and prognosis to the next level by integrating high fidelity physics model and advanced data analytics methods.

Besides the research contributions on the new technological development, the interdisciplinary nature of this project provided students the unique opportunity to obtain training in data analytics, dynamics, and mechanical structures. Through the development of new course materials and research training for participating graduate students, this project made positive impacts on the human resource development.

 


Last Modified: 09/23/2021
Modified by: Shiyu Zhou
